frameworkBody:
Covid Act Now worked alongside a network of research, policy, and public health experts convened by Harvard’s Global Health Institute and Edmond J. Safra Center for Ethics to develop the [Key Metrics for COVID Suppression](https://globalhealth.harvard.edu/key-metrics-for-covid-suppression-researchers-and-public-health-experts-unite-to-bring-clarity-to-key-metrics-guiding-coronavirus-response/) framework.

Central to this framework is our five-color COVID warning system, which communicates the severity of a location’s outbreak and offers corresponding guidance on mitigation efforts needed at each risk level. This facilitates a unified approach with common metrics, enabling leaders at all levels to anticipate and adequately respond to their community’s COVID spread, and informing the general public on their community’s risk to COVID. To develop this framework, we prioritized metrics vital to guiding suppression efforts that allow a community to safely reopen.
metadataTitle: Risk Levels and Key Metrics for COVID-19
metadataDescription: Understand the Risk Levels in your community and COVID Metrics: daily new cases, infection rate, positive test rate, ICU capacity used, contact tracing.

sections.sectionIntro:
A state or county’s overall risk level takes into account three metrics: daily new cases per 100K (incidence), infection rate (Rt), and test positivity. 

* [Daily new cases](/covid-risk-levels-metrics#daily-new-cases), also known as “incidence” in epidemiology, represents the current amount of COVID in a community. 
* [Infection rate](/covid-risk-levels-metrics#infection-rate) is the direction and speed of growth. For instance, daily new cases may be low, but if infection rate is high, then we know that daily new cases will be high in the near future. 
* [Positive test rate](/covid-risk-levels-metrics#positive-test-rate) is a measure of our confidence in the underlying data. For instance, if daily new cases and infection rate are both low, but test positivity is high, then the lack of sufficient testing suggests that we are not capturing the true levels of COVID and both daily new cases and infection rate are actually higher than what is currently reported. 

Each metric has the following levels: green, yellow, orange, and red. Incidence is the only metric for which there is a dark red, a fifth color we added after the third surge in winter 2020, in order to capture unprecedented case counts. 

If a region’s daily new cases is green, then its overall risk level is green. For instance, if the daily new cases metric is green, but test positivity is yellow, the overall risk level is still green. Otherwise, a region’s overall risk level reflects the highest risk level across all three metrics. For instance, if daily new cases and test positivity are both yellow, but infection growth is orange, then the overall risk level is orange. 

The end goal is for regions to reduce cases to zero, to fully reopen their economies, and for people to resume normal lives, unrestricted by COVID or containment measures.

questions.answer: Covid Act Now partnered with the Harvard Global Health Institute and Harvard Edmond J. Safra Center for Ethics to develop our COVID risk framework. As there has not been a standardized risk framework across the U.S., it may not match your state or county's risk levels. Our framework is the result of collaboration between public health, epidemiology, and policy experts from the following organizations:

sections.sectionIntro: **Daily new cases is the number of new COVID cases per day per unit of population** (we measure per 100K people).

questions.question: Sources and methodology
questions.answer:
Our daily new cases number is a seven-day average, and divided by every 100K people in a location. For instance, if a location has 200K people, we would divide the daily new cases by two.

![Daily new cases metric calculation](/images_cms/daily-new-cases-calculation.png)

To calculate daily new cases, we use new positive cases [from The New York Times](https://developer.nytimes.com/covid).

questions.question: Levels
questions.answer:
Levels for daily new cases are based on the [“Key](https://ethics.harvard.edu/files/center-for-ethics/files/key_metrics_and_indicators_v4.pdf) [Metrics for Covid Suppression”](https://ethics.harvard.edu/files/center-for-ethics/files/key_metrics_and_indicators_v4.pdf) by Harvard Global Health Institute and others. 

The deepest color indicates severe outbreak, for locations with daily new cases above 75 cases/100K.

questions.question: Limitations
questions.answer:
Our case data faces several limitations due to lack of federal reporting standards.

1. Not all states specify and report both confirmed and probable COVID cases. Confirmed cases are those that have been confirmed by PCR test and probable cases are counted by assumptions based on epidemiological evidence like antigen tests and reported symptoms. A state may report only confirmed cases, both confirmed and probable cases separately, or the two together without specification.
2. There are also inconsistencies when patients move across counties or when a patient’s treatment location is not reported.

Credible data sources such as The New York Times (NYT) work to address these limitations by interpreting and verifying the data, and counting patients based on where they are being treated rather than where they live, when possible.

questions.question: More information on daily new cases
questions.answer:
[What is R-naught (R₀) and how is it different from R(t)?](https://covidactnow.org/faq#r-0-vs-r-t)

[Video explainer](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_S0k1I3kIbM)

sections.sectionIntro: **Infection rate is the estimated number of new people each COVID-positive person will infect.**

questions.question: Sources and methodology
questions.answer:
This one is a bit complicated. To calculate the infection growth, a mathematical model combines trends in daily new cases from approximately the last 14 days, with estimates for other variables, such as how many days on average occur between infection and transmission.

To calculate the infection rate, we use new positive cases [from The New York Times](https://developer.nytimes.com/covid).

questions.question: Levels
questions.answer:
In order to control COVID, the infection rate, or R(t), must be driven below 1.0 until the daily new cases metric is green. At that point community spread is effectively stopped and we can focus on controlling isolated outbreaks. 

We use 0.9 as the cutoff for a green score because at that rate the number of newly infected people begins to significantly decline. An R(t) of 1.0 means that the daily new cases of COVID are stable, while an R(t) greater than 1.0 means that daily new cases are growing.

questions.question: Limitations
questions.answer:
Because you can’t measure infection rate directly, our estimates hinge upon our epidemiological assumptions and the accuracy of our data sources. 

1. Infection rate can only track COVID growth once a positive case gets reported through the system. By then, infectious individuals have likely been COVID positive for some time, so the metric will always lag the true risk on the ground. For example, if someone was exposed over the holidays, they likely didn’t test positive until the new year.
2. Infection rate should be considered in context with the other metrics. Daily new cases refers to the number of new COVID infections, while the infection rate represents the trend. A place with high daily new cases may have an infection rate less than 1 and still have higher exposure than a place with relatively few, but growing, cases.

questions.question: More information on infection rate
questions.answer:
[Why is infection rate important?](https://covidactnow.org/faq#infection-rate-important)

[Video explainer](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dmp5iAXrkaY&t=0s)

sections.sectionIntro: **Positive test rate is the *percentage* of COVID PCR testing that comes back positive** (not the total number of positive PCR tests).

questions.question: Sources and methodology
questions.answer:
Positive test rate is calculated by dividing the number of positive PCR tests over the last 7 days by the total number of PCR tests over the last 7 days. It is important to note that the positive test rate can be difficult to interpret and messy to calculate, for reasons well captured by the [Covid Tracking Project](https://covidtracking.com/blog/test-positivity-in-the-us-is-a-mess). It should be looked at in conjunction with other metrics such as infection rate and daily new cases.

We source state level testing data from the [Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)](https://healthdata.gov/dataset/COVID-19-Diagnostic-Laboratory-Testing-PCR-Testing/j8mb-icvb) and county/metro level testing data from the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Covid Data Tracker](https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#county-view). Check out your location’s page for more details.

questions.question: Levels
questions.answer:
There is a growing [consensus](https://globalhealth.harvard.edu/evidence-roundup-why-positive-test-rates-need-to-fall-below-3/) that driving the positive test rate downwards of 3 percent should be a priority, which is why we have set 3 percent as the threshold for the lowest level.

It can also be helpful to look at countries that have been most effective and efficient in their containment of COVID. South Korea was back to normal activity with a test positivity rate below 3 percent. As of November 2020, [South Korea’s test positivity](http://ncov.mohw.go.kr/en/) was 1 percent.

questions.question: Limitations
questions.answer:
States report testing data in ways that can make comparisons difficult.

1. Some states combine [PCR](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#pcr-test) and rapid testing, also referred to as [antigen](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#antigen-test) testing.
2. Some states track positive tests while others track people who test positive. So someone who takes three tests and eventually tests positive may be counted in noticeably different ways depending on whether the state tracks tests, people, or encounters.

Federal data sets such as the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) attempt to standardize fragmented testing data by representing diagnostic specimens and excluding non-PCR tests. [Learn more about the current state of federal testing data and its limitations](https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/federal-testing-datas-last-mile/).

questions.question: More information on positive test rate
questions.answer:
[What does positive test rate tell us?](https://covidactnow.org/faq#what-does-positive-test-rate-tell-us)

[Video explainer](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RpqI-ZVGGoY)

questions.question: More information on COVID testing
questions.answer:
[Why is testing important? ](https://covidactnow.org/faq#why-is-testing-important)

[How soon after a possible exposure to COVID should I get tested?](https://covidactnow.org/faq#covid-how-soon-after-exposure-tested)

[Are rapid tests less accurate than PCR tests?](https://covidactnow.org/faq#rapid-tests-less-accurate-than-pcr)

[The Potential Role of Antigen Testing in the Pandemic](https://covidactnow.org/covid-explained/potential-role-antigen-tests-pandemic)

sections.sectionIntro: **ICU capacity used measures the number of intensive care unit (ICU) beds that are currently in use.**

questions.question: Sources and methodology
questions.answer:
We calculate ICU capacity by taking the number of staffed ICU beds that are occupied (by both COVID and Non-COVID patients) and dividing it by the total number of staffed ICU beds. We use data from the [Department of Health and Human Services (HHS)](https://healthdata.gov/Hospital/COVID-19-Reported-Patient-Impact-and-Hospital-Capa/g62h-syeh) to calculate the metric. This data is provided to the HHS via three sources: (1) HHS TeleTracking, (2) reporting provided directly to HHS Protect by state/territorial health departments on behalf of their healthcare facilities and (3) National Healthcare Safety Network (before July 15).

For more details, see your location’s page.

questions.question: Levels
questions.answer:
[Studies](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3840149/#:~:text=The%20mean%20hourly%20occupancy%20for,ICUs%20(P%20%3D%200.036).) have found that, on average, before the pandemic, U.S. ICUs operated at about 68 percent of full capacity. However, that number depends heavily on things like the overall size of the hospital and the urban or rural region it serves. For instance, a small hospital with only four ICU beds running at 75 percent of full capacity has only one bed available, whereas a larger hospital with 100 ICU beds running at 75 percent of full capacity has twenty five ICU beds available.

So smaller hospitals with only a few (three to four) staffed ICU beds typically have lower occupancy (30 percent to 50 percent), and generally have a system for transferring critically ill patients to larger hospitals. Meanwhile, larger hospitals tend to run fuller, with higher ICU usage (60 percent to 80 percent). 

In general, experts agree that as ICU capacity usage approaches 85 percent, the likelihood of an abrupt outbreak overwhelming hospital systems increases. At such levels of ICU usage, NPIs ([nonpharmaceutical interventions](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#npi)), ranging from business closures to stay-at-home orders, may be needed to prevent a hospital system’s ICU from being overwhelmed, which means that it would not be able to serve patients in need of any type of lifesaving care. For instance, in California, the [California Department of Public Health (CDPH)](https://www.gov.ca.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/12.3.20-Stay-at-Home-Order-ICU-Scenario.pdf) calls for stay-at-home orders when this 85 percent threshold is met.

questions.question: Limitations
questions.answer:
This data is closely watched by HHS, but nevertheless, there may be missing or incorrect data. Data may be lost or distorted as it is reported from hospitals to local, state, and federal agencies, such as the HHS. 

The biggest source of uncertainty in this metric is the ability for a hospital to quickly expand beyond its normal capacity to meet increased demand. This “[surge” capacity](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#surge-capacity) is difficult to predict in advance because it depends on both physical hospital resources like available beds and non-physical resources like healthy nurses and doctors to run them.

HHS tries to control for this by requiring that hospitals report staffed ICU beds on a daily basis, but this doesn’t give a complete picture about theoretical surge capacity.

questions.question: More information on ICU capacity used
questions.answer: [Why is ICU capacity used important?](https://covidactnow.org/faq#why-icu-capacity-used-important)

sections.sectionIntro: **% Vaccinated is the percentage of the total population in a given location that has started the vaccination process.**

questions.question: Sources and methodology
questions.answer:
Our vaccination metric tracks the percentage of the total population in each location that has initiated vaccination, not limited to those who are 12 and older. Someone has initiated vaccination if they have received the first shot of any of the currently available vaccines (Pfizer, Moderna, J&J). For context, we also include in our graphs the percentage of people who have completed vaccination. Someone has completed vaccination if they have completed the recommended number of shots (one shot for J&J, two shots for Pfizer and Moderna).

Our primary source for state vaccination data is the [CDC COVID Data Tracker](https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations). For counties, we use a combination of state and federal data sources. If a state dashboard provides county level data on vaccinations initiated (1+ dose) and vaccinations completed, we use that data directly. If not, we take the completed vaccination data from the CDC and estimate vaccinations initiated using the fully-vaccinated data and a state-wide average ratio.

questions.question: Limitations
questions.answer:
The vaccination data we show contains a number of limitations: 

1. **Vaccine vs. infection-acquired immunity**: We focus on vaccine-acquired immunity and do not account for infection-acquired immunity. At this time, we are not sufficiently confident in the ability to estimate vaccine-acquired plus infection-acquired immunity. We will revisit this choice if the CDC puts out more information about general seroprevalence and the infection history of people getting vaccinated. 
2. **Number of shots**: For the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines, we require two shots to consider someone as having completed vaccination. This stays close to the available science and the advice of experts, including many of our advisors. The J&J vaccine is designed to only require one shot to count as completed.
3. **Permanence of immunity**: Until we know more, we assume that someone who has completed vaccination stays immune for the foreseeable future, and we do not try to estimate waning immunity. 
4. **Vaccine variations**: We treat all vaccine manufacturers equally, e.g. our data combines people who have received the Pfizer, Moderna, and J&J vaccines. We will re-evaluate this with any additional data, especially as more types of vaccines become available. 
5. **Timeliness**: We get our national and state data from the CDC, which does not always update daily. There are currently unavoidable delays from the provider to the CDC and from the CDC to the public.

questions.question: More information on COVID vaccines
questions.answer:
[Information on vaccine safety, eligibility, and immunity](https://covidactnow.org/faq#vaccines)

[Variants and Vaccines ](https://covidactnow.org/covid-explained/covid-variants-vaccines)

[A Round up of Current Vaccine Progress](https://covidactnow.org/covid-explained/roundup-current-vaccine-progress)

[The Demographic Make-Up of COVID Vaccine Trials](https://covidactnow.org/covid-explained/covid-vaccine-trials)

[The Basics of COVID Vaccine Development](https://covidactnow.org/covid-explained/covid-vaccine-basics)

sections.sectionIntro:
**Communities with higher vulnerability have pre-existing economic, social, and physical conditions that may make it hard to respond to and recover from a COVID outbreak.**

As of May 18, 2021, people in the *most* vulnerable third of U.S. counties are 47 percent more likely to have died from COVID than people in the *least* vulnerable third of U.S. counties ([see source](https://precisionforcovid.org/ccvi)).  

This is due to a number of factors such as a community members’ income, age, and underlying health, as well as their access to transportation and health care.

questions.question: Sources and methodology
questions.answer:
We use a score calculated by [Surgo Ventures](https://precisionforcovid.org/ccvi), a nonprofit with expertise in behavioral and data science. Known as the COVID-19 Community Vulnerability Index (CCVI), this index compares states, counties, and metros across the U.S. and ranks their vulnerability relative to each other, for example with the least vulnerable county assigned a score of 0 percent, and the most vulnerable county in the U.S. with a score of 100 percent, meaning it is more vulnerable than 100 of counties in the U.S. A location’s vulnerability score looks at seven different factors: 

* **Unemployment & low income**: Financial insecurity, lack of access to health care, or the inability to work remotely or with protections and benefits increases vulnerability to severe COVID outcomes.
* **Minorities & non-English speakers**: Language barriers can restrict access to public health messaging and resources. Data on COVID has demonstrated that racial and ethnic minorities are often at the highest risk of poor medical outcomes.
* **Housing & transport challenges**: Crowded housing, housing insecurity, access to indoor plumbing and limited transit options make it more difficult to avoid COVID exposure.
* **Older age & health issues**: High-risk groups (per CDC guidelines) such as elderly adults or people with pre-existing conditions have experienced more severe health outcomes throughout the pandemic.
* **Health system challenges**: Hospital bed availability, access to pharmacies, and the amount of healthcare spending per capita within a region, among other factors, can indicate the limited capacity of healthcare systems to respond to COVID.
* **Crowded living & working areas**: High-risk environments, such as prisons, nursing homes, or factories, significantly contribute to a person's exposure to and vulnerability to the virus.
* **Population density**: Higher population density has been demonstrated to increase the risk of quick viral spread and adverse health outcomes. Given its importance in understanding vulnerability to the pandemic, it comprises a specific theme in the index.

Surgo Ventures sources their data from the CDC, Centers for Medicare, & Medicaid Services (CMS), the Harvard Global Health Institute, PolicyMap, the U.S Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), the U.S. Census Bureau (USCB), the National Cancer Institute (NCI), the National Center for HIV, STD and TB Prevention (NCHSTP), Kaiser Health News, Census Economic Annual Surveys, the Vera institute for Justice, and the Association of Public Health Laboratories (APHL).

The CCVI is updated whenever new research about risk factors for COVID becomes available. Thus far it's been updated approximately every 4-6 months, but this may change. The way the CCVI is calculated may also change in the future, for instance to take into account economic recovery.

questions.question: Limitations
questions.answer:
Vulnerability is a complex issue, and it does not look the same in every community and through every lens. There are several limitations of the CCVI data to keep in mind: 

* The index is an estimate of vulnerability and does not account for every factor which may make an individual or community at higher risk of COVID disease or death. 
* For the most complete understanding of a community’s vulnerability, the index should be used in conjunction with COVID statistics and data on public response, such as test site locations, [nonpharmaceutical interventions (NPIs)](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#npi), and vaccine distribution. 
* The CCVI may not capture all at-risk essential worker groups represented in the “crowded living and working areas” special vulnerability.

questions.question: Still have more questions?
questions.answer: For further details, read [](https://docs.google.com/document/d/142EPwY0GqcSJlsD2fJOHIg_2G4e2ksxy8iToJ7maP4Y/edit)[Surgo’s methodology and sourcing document](https://covid-static-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/US-CCVI/COVID-19+Community+Vulnerability+Index+(CCVI)+Methodology.pdf).

questions.question: More information on vulnerability
questions.answer:
[Why vulnerability data is important for all communities ](/covid-explained/covid-vulnerability-data)

[Resources for vulnerable people](/covid-explained/federal-resources-covid-relief)

pageIntro: Covid Act Now uses six key metrics to assess COVID across U.S. states, metros, and counties. Three of these—[daily new cases](#daily-new-cases) (incidence), [infection rate](#infection-rate) (RT) and [positive test rate](#positive-test-rate)—assess a location's overall risk level. The other three—[ICU capacity used](#icu-capacity-used), [% vaccinated](#percent-vaccinated) and [vulnerability](https://covidactnow.org/covid-risk-levels-metrics#vulnerability)—reflect a location's ability to protect itself and recover from COVID. Below, learn more about each metric and how it is assessed.
